channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ecuador Family Wins Favors After Donations to Obama Campaign
item.description: A scion of the Isaías family, whose members are wanted for fraud in Ecuador, had her entry ban waived as Senator Robert Menendez lobbied Hillary Rodham Clinton’s office and the family poured tens of thousands into Democratic coffers.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Estefanía Isaías had been banned from entering the United States for visa fraud. The ban was later waived.

item.title: In Sydney Hostage Siege, Australia’s New Antiterrorism Measures Proved Ineffective
item.description: Recently passed antiterrorism laws in Australia did not prevent a man known to the police from laying siege to a cafe in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Attack on Peshawar School Leaves 145 Dead
item.description: Gunmen stormed a school in the northwestern city of Peshawar, killing students and teachers and battling security forces for more than eight hours, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Car Bombs in Yemen Kill Dozens, Including Schoolchildren
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombings in the central city of Rada, but suspicion fell on Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: John Osburg on the Angst Found Among China’s Newly Rich
item.description: A new book by John Osburg, “Anxious Wealth: Money and Morality Among China’s New Rich,” paints a rich picture of the complex ways in which men and women try to buy favors and get ahead in business ventures, often by courting government officials at night clubs and often over drinking and sex.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian in Raid of West Bank Camp
item.description: The Israeli military said soldiers opened fire after explosives were thrown at them in the Qalandia refugee camp in the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Vatican Report Cites Achievements and Challenges of U.S. Nuns
item.description: Its relatively warm tone was a far cry from six years ago when the investigation of American nuns was announced, creating fear, anger and mistrust among women in religious communities and convents.
item.dc:creator: By LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: From left; Mother Mary Clare Millea; the Rev. Thomas Rosica; Cardinal Joao Braz de Aviz of Brazil; Sister Sharon Holland; and Mother Agnes Mary Donovan at the Vatican on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Calm Israeli and Palestinian Tensions
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said the United States had made “no determinations” about efforts toward Security Council resolutions on the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry at the United States Embassy in London on Tuesday.

item.title: E.U. Confirms Wide Fraud in Afghan Presidential Runoff Election
item.description: The report from European Union election observers offered the fullest picture yet of the allegations of fraud that plagued the election.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Britons, Austerity Can Be Relative
item.description: As the government plans spending cuts, lawmakers are resisting efforts to reduce their budget as well.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Save a Few Pennies on Champagne? Lawmakers in Britain’s House of Lords Are Aghast
item.description: Members of the upper house of Parliament are facing outrage over reports that they rejected a proposal to save money on lawmakers’ bubbly.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, delivered a budget statement earlier this month implying $86 billion in spending cuts, including a Champagne subsidy for the House of Lords.

item.title: As Election Looms, Britain Ponders ‘English Question’
item.description: After Scotland won more powers in its rejection of independence, the burning question now is deciding how to deal with measures that concern only England.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: New Russia Sanctions Bill Will Be Signed by Obama, White House Says
item.description: President Obama will sign the bill despite concerns it will complicate efforts to maintain a unified front with European allies, the White House said.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: World Briefing: Autopsy Ordered for German Lawmaker Who Criticized Russia
item.description: The authorities said the autopsy would be carried out to counter speculation after the sudden death on Saturday of the lawmaker, Andreas Schockenhoff.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Israel Cracks Down on a Group Tied to Anti-Arab Acts
item.description: Ten members of Lehava, a far-right Jewish group, were arrested on suspicion of incitement and calls for acts of violence motivated by racism, a day after three were arrested in an arson case.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Q. and A.: How the Pakistani Taliban Became a Deadly Force
item.description: Formally founded in 2007, a group traces its roots to cross-border radicalization spread by the Afghan Taliban and fighters from Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL, DECLAN WALSH and DOUGLAS SCHORZMAN
item.media:description: Pakistani Army troopers moving toward the Red Mosque during a military operation in Islamabad in July 2007.

item.title: Russia’s Steep Rate Increase Fails to Stem Ruble’s Decline
item.description: Despite the Russian central bank’s extraordinary effort to defend the ruble, the currency fell to record lows, inducing further panic in the nation’s financial industry.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at an electronics shop in Moscow. Fearing inflation, Russians are reacting to the falling ruble by snapping up expensive items like appliances and laptops.

item.title: Turkey Promotes Religious Schools, Often Defying Parents
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whose Islamist party has injected religion into many aspects of Turkish life, has celebrated an increase in enrollment at religious schools to almost a million from 63,000 during his 12 years in power.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:credit: Kayhan Ozer/Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan during a ceremony in Kocaeli, Turkey, on Monday.

item.title: 2014 Was Deadliest Year for Migrants, International Group Says
item.description: At least 4,868 people have perished so far this year, over double the 2,400 deaths recorded last year, the International Organization for Migration reported.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Bill Hayton on Growing Rivalries in the South China Sea
item.description: The BBC journalist’s latest work, “The South China Sea: The Struggle for Power in Asia,” addresses the history, politics and energy resources of the sea that has become central to China’s foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Bill Hayton says the islands of the South China Sea are difficult for a foreign journalist to visit.
